supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation. Some bore holes caused by insects.

origin.origDate: No internal date. Before 1855, as it is part of Ariel’s bequest made in that year to the Société Asiatique, Paris (Rosny 1869). 1840 according to Cabaton (1912, p. 49). The reason for this date is unknown.

acquisition.p: Bequest of Edouard Ariel. Made first to Société Asiatique de Paris in 1855, later transfered to Bibliothèque Nationale (see Rosny 1869).

revisionDesc.change: This catalogue entry has been redacted by Emmanuel FRANCIS (CNRS, CEIAS UMR 8564, EHESS/CNRS) for the research program Texts Surrounding Texts (TST, FRAL 2018, ANR/DFG). Version 1, May 2020.

body.p: The Kantapurāṇacurukkam is an epitome (curukkam) of the Kantapurāṇam, in verse, by Campantacaraṇālayacuvāmi. From Raghavan (1960, p. 232), we learn that Campantacaraṇālayacuvāmi was a scholar in Tamil, Telugu and Kannada, attached to the Dharmapuram Mutt, and that he wrote this epitome (in 1049 stanzas) at the instance of the Mysore Ruler.
Other manuscript testimonies of this text are: GOML D. 546, D. 5479 (see Rangacharya & Kuppusvami Sastri 1916, p. 526ff.).
The palm-leaf bundle, a single-text manuscript, contains between the two woodcovers:
U1: 1 folio, unfoliated = title-page, by hand n° 1. With shelfmark: B/55.
U3: 107 folios, Tamil foliation 1– 107 = text (mūlam), by several hands, different from hand n° 1. 7 to 10 lines per page.

The copying of the manuscript was a collective work as indicated by the different recognizable hands and the variety of the foliations. There are also blank but foliated folios, one interesting and enigmatic case being U2, f77 (blank except for piḷḷaiyār cuḻi and foliation), whereas there is no text discontinuity between between f76v (first part of stanza n° 27) and f78r (second part of stanza n° 28). Furthermore, there are in-text chapter completion statements not matching the marginal chapter headers in the preceding folios.
The text is incomplete. A third of the Yuttakāṇṭam, the whole of the Tēvakāṇṭam, and almost half of the Takṣakāṇṭam are missing.

Paratexts: marginal and in-text benedictions, invocation page, marginal title, marginal chapter headers, marginal sub-chapter headers [the Yuttakāṇṭam is subdivided in sections, each with an independent numbering of the stanzas], in-text chapter completion statement, in-text total stanzas, addendum (U2, f[1]v).

U1, folio 1, recto, unfoliated = title-page: marginal benediction, title.
(f[1]r, lm, 1–3) veṟṟivēl uṟṟa tuṇai
(f[1]r1–2) kantappurāṇaccurukkam

U2, folio 1, recto, unfoliated = invocation: marginal benediction, 1 invocatory stanza, distributed aṭi-wise on the page.
(f[1]r, lm, 1–2) vēyuṟutōḷipaṅkaṉ ṟuṇai
(f[1]r1) poṅku kantap purāṇac curukkanū ‡
(f[1]r2) liṅki caittiṭa viṉpoṭu muṟṟuvāṉ ‡
(f[1]r3) maṅkai pālakaṉ mātaṅka māmukap ‡
(f[1]r4) puṅka vaṉṟuṇaip poṟpatam pōṟṟuvām {pcs}

U2, folio 1, verso, unfoliated = addendum: doctrinal definitions. Indented towards the right; line 1 only is blackened.
(f[1]v1) caṭākkaram-āṉatu = namō kumārāya
(f[1]v2) mummalam = Āṇavam = kāḻiyam = māyai
(f[1]v3) AIntoḻiṟku = ciruṣṣi = titi = caṅkāram
(f[1]v4) tiropāvam = Aṉukkirakam
(f[1]v5) talai = Upaniṣatam-āṉatu

U3, folio 1, recto = incipit: marginal benediction, title, and chapter header; Pāyiram, invocatory stanza n° 1.
(f1r, lm, 1–2) tiruccittampalampalam [corrected by the scribe to tirucciṟṟampalam]
(f1r, lm, 3–5) kantappurāṇaccurukkam
(f1r, lm, 6–8) Uṟpattiy(ar) kāṇṭam.
(f1r1) cīrkoṇṭa vāṉanta vuruva [i.e. vāṉanta; vuruva is marked by the scribe with superscript dots and crossed-out, but unblackened, by a user of the MS] māki yeṅkuñ ceṟivākip paramākit tiramatāki ‡ yērkoṇṭa karuṇaitiru vuruvamāki yeḻilkoṇṭa
(f1r2) malaimakaḷai yiṭattiṟ koṇṭōṉ ‡ kārkoṇṭa(n) [i.e. kārkoṇṭa] niṟuṅkoṇṭa [i.e. niraṅkoṇṭa] mukunta(ña)tik [i.e. mukuntaṉātik] kaṭavuḷarvan taṭiparavuṅ kaṭavuḷ koṉṟait ‡ tār
(f1r3) koṇṭa muṭiyaṉava ṉaṭiyait tāḻntu tāḻāta peruṅkatiyil vāḻā niṟpām = 1 = (…)

U3, folio 107, recto and verso= excipit: Teṣṣaṇ Kāṇtam (f92r, lm) [i.e. Takṣakāṇṭam], stanza n° 140.
(f107r9) (…) = 139 = kāvi ṉayaṉak kalacamulai kāḷiyeṉun ‡ tēviyōṭu niṉṟa tiṟalāḷa ṉīticaippak ‡ kōviṉ micaiyē-
(f107v1) ṟuṅ kōvai yitaḻntu moḻi ‡ nāvi [i.e. tāvi] koṭuppā ṉavikoṭē ṉeṉṟaṉṉē ‡‡
[The text stops abruptly here].

Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso. GOML = Government Oriental Manuscripts Library, Madras/Chennai. MTL = Madras Tamil Lexicon. TMSSML = Tanjore Maharaja Serfoji Sarasvati Mahal Library.

Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is not clearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible. aṭi boundary marked by "‡".
